Posted: November 25, 2016
												This is a MMORPG. The usual aspects are all there. The grinding, the level, the cosmetics, the cash grab. Apart from all that however, it is surprisingly fun. The dynamic combat system varies from class to class; no two classes play the same way. Skills trees are varied and unique, and is overall implements a pretty seamless fighting style. The graphic are mediocre at best, with rather outdated texutres and sometimes glitchy models, but is certainly acceptable. The game is poorly optimized for AMD GPUs be warned, it is very hard to run at smooth FPS's, and textures will sometimes not display properly.Overall very fun time killer, though some polishing would definetly help.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Dragon Nest is a game from Nexon, the evil minds behind Maple Story. This game plays very much like Vindictus with various tiers of difficulty in each mission area, different loot, different bosses/moves/hp imcreased, etc. The thing that separates this from Vindictus is the cuteness of it all. This is a very "cute" game where everything is nice and bright and the conversations you have with NPC's are downright funny quite often. You never know what they'll end up talking to you about before you accept a quest or are just improving relations with them.You can pick a few different classes but they are all gender locked. A fighter is male and a sorceress is female for example.This game is hard to describe if you haven't played Vindictus because that game has very similar ....everything! It's just a tad more.You can crafticular mission area and so on. It's worth trying this game just to see if you like it. I often sit down intending to do just one mission or two and end up playing for hours. Definitely the sign of a good game.

												This is easily the best MMO I have ever played. The combat in this game is the only 1 of its kind. Very fast paced and fluid. It feels and looks amazing when taking down huge groups of enemies in seconds. There will be almost 50 different job classes when the Assassin is released. Lots of different things to do besides just questing. Huge achievement system. The dialog is well written and humorous on most NPCs. Theres no reason not to play this when its a free game.Edit: Assassin is released!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Cons:  -RNG on RNG gearing system makes gearing difficult and time consuming  -People who treat the game like a job neglect new players  -Your tickets will be answered within 1-5 years (Literally)  -Game has had past troubles balancing classes and gameplay  -Can get repetitive and requires much grinding  -Gender locked classes with limited customization  -Early game leveling ends up being mostly soloed and everything is end game based  -An often lack of communication in what the game wants: may be hard for new players to get used toPros:  -Brilliantly fun fast paced action combat system  -A rather kind community overall, with exceptions as always.  -Challenging skill based PvP  -A wide range of classes to choose from  -Fast paced leveling  -A very manga plot if you're into that  -Not Open world (It is instance based); which I like but can be a turn off for others  -Interesting mechanics that require the players to learn the battle's ins and outs  -Always something new to get excited about  -Easy to get sucked in for all eternityI'd like to say, for those salty over Mists of Peril the update wasn't a shock, really. I was actually grossly excited about T5 finally fixing all the issues: the class discrimination, the elemental party imbalances, and I even like the new UI after I finally got used to it. I will miss the old content, as some of it I never got the chance to enjoy, but what can anyone really do?T5 was a long overdue update and altogether I think T5 has improved the game,except RNG on RNG. But I don't think that'll ever get fixed.You can expect an action MMORPG, with a not quite as in-your-face 'give us money' campaign as compared to a lot of other free MMO's. If you hold vanity as a need you'll see a lot more difficulty on that front, as well as if you treat the game like a job and need the best of everything.You can do end game content with a little effort without putting money in, but some people will always have a stick up their bottom trying to be better than everyone else. The game will be work if you do that though.What makes me adore the game is and always has been the combat though. It is unlike anything I've had the pleasure to enjoy in other games.As a veteran player whose put over 100 hours into the steam version, and at least 300-500 hours prior to getting the game on steam, I recommend the game, with all its troubles.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19
												What got MY attention and hooked to this game:- The fast paced combat: Although each class has their respective roles, you can have the same fast paced fun with just about any of the classess to choose from. Which makes it super satisfying when you successfully create your own skill chain combos, and ends up either completely destroying groups of mobs in pve or players in pvp.- All the classes to choose from: Cleric was a blast for me as my first class, Warrior gave me a whole new meaning of power, Sorceress made me think twice when fighting against magic. I can honestly say the skill/abilities from each class are absolutely cool, creative, flashy, and work brilliantly well together in whatever order you want.- Things aside from pve/pvp: Oddly enough for me I found the fishing, cooking, and farming very fun. Cooking made me realize how useful the items can be in this game, wanting to explore and learn more recipes to test them in dungeons. Fishing can be surprisely difficult to do unless you autofish instead for a more relaxing time. Farming can be your secondary source of income of ingame cash.Sure there are cosmetics/costumes that give bonus stats, the grind is a living hell, pvp can be either really fun or just absoultely a broken gamemode for others. But the majority of the community is friendly and actively helping new players when they ask for it. The story is surprisingly interesting but abit lenghty, and for this type of art-style, the general scenery and structures you see both in a town or dungeon are stunning and give a hint of nostalgic feeling (at least for me)

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												While I have played this game for a long time, I've had my fun with it. The combo system is good, but rarely has any effects on actual gameplay other than PVP where literally you cannot win without better stats. This game isn't as Skill to Win as it used to be, according to most of my friends who have played it for a long time. Although this game has a pretty good base and whatnot, grinding on the same dungeons just becomes really boring. Do I recommend this game? Yes and no.The PVP system is a bit flawed, but I can see where it has its fun parts. The dungeon and EXP system itself are pretty good, looting system along with them. But I do not encourage buying stuff in this game with real money, since it's pretty much just a waste.The variety of classes in this game is also a good thing to mention. But some classes definitely rise up higher than others do, which really disappoints me.The story becomes really repetitive but the only entertaining parts are when you get to actually see the story of your own character. Other than that, it's just the main story of the game.As I said, I don't exactly recommend this game but I have solid hopes for it.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Dragon Nest is a fun game for those tired of tab-targetting games. It is fast paced and entertaining. I will list some of the pros and some of the cons to the game.Pros:-Cute chibi style animation-Unique classes and specializations-Live-action combat (yes you have to aim)-Good story-Supports different playstyles (pvp, pve elitists, and pve casuals)-Leveling is pretty easy-Decent ability to replay (reroll multiple characters)Cons:-Repetitive quests (you will have to do the same dungeon several times)-Not new player friendly (takes a lot of getting used to as far as crafting, build guides, rotations, and how to obtain gear)-Not very challenging until higher levels-Cosmetics (costumes, while visually appealing, give stats and you have to pay real money for them, I am cheap so no thank you)-Small community (good luck finding answers to your questions, most people just wing it)-The running animation is hilarious in the worst way for all classesWhen all is said and done it is a very fun game that is easy to get into but difficult to get into competitive content. I would label it more as a casual game. For a free to play game it is not pay to win, but it is pay to look better than everyone else and have a bit of an edge as far as stats if you buy costumes and pets. It may not be perfect but it is a great game to kick back with friends who are tired of playing other things.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												1. 7 classes with dynamic, purely skilled based combat...HOWEVER many classes are nerfed to the point of uselessness, so join the bandwagon classes or enjoy playing alone. Parties seek specific classes/will not play with specific certain classes so do your research first. Unbalanced class system. This applies to both PVP and PVE, but mostly to PVE. PVP is awesome and absolutely skill based, with equipment not so much [they nerf equipment to balance the playing field a little, better equipment is still advantageous].2. Plenty of guilds/active player base... HOWEVER they're not the cream of the crop people, there are nice players but more than half the time you'll deal with immature ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that devote a bit too much time [and real life money, with microtransactions reaching several hundred dollars] on this game. That being said, if you're looking for VERY active people to regularly play with, this is the right game.3. Free to play entirely... HOWEVER the microtransactions does give VERY NICE boosts in-game. For example, end game you might have.. 800k HP. But with a $30 costume, you can have 900k HP without having to buy expensive gear. Costumes can also boost your movement speed [some classes are SLOW AS HELL], which is kind of nice. Some costumes are really cool, like robotic wings... or a dragon mount/pet... even fun things like a fluffy sheep.4. Unbelievable amounts of grinding, there's no way to avoid this. You can buy powerlevels, have fun with that. Grinding for max level then for decent gear, because the bosses hit HARD and unless your skills can avoid the bills, keep farming that gear. Also when partying with people they won't even play with you if you have bad gear... so YOU BETTER GRIND.5.  Speaking of #3 and #4, microtransactions can be used to.. avoid grinding for money a bit. You can buy items with real life money, and sell in game for gold.6. Noncombat skills available, just not purely combat oriented. HOWEVER ... 3 skills: cooking, fishing, farming. No one fishes/fishing is completely useless. Cooking is likewise the same and the ingredients for cooking are so weird/hard to obtain that it's not worth it [have to rely on RNG drop rates, not gathering]. Farms are overpacked/almost impossible to obtain farm spots unless you can acquire a few spots and obsessively watch over your spot so no one else takes it.7. Great story lines.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Okay, I'm just gonna start listing♥♥♥♥♥♥right off the bat here. -Pros.The combat is well executed, as to have reflex-based combat, instead of targeting, as do most other RPG's have that.Customization was okay, would have preferred there to be a bit more variety, armor wise, though. Excellent storyline, probably the best thing about this game. Animations for the skills are cool as hell to watch, as well as the skills themselves. Speaking of skills, very wide choice of skills, and specializations for your desired class. Graphics are brilliant, very well drawn, and simple. The way they should be. Isn't as pay to win as I thought it was gonna be.-Cons. REALLY, REAAALLLLYYY grind-esque experience, most of the game I was either grinding my character to the cap level, {which they are ALWAYS, changing.} Or, I'm paying others gold to boost me to those said higher levels. Game speed isn't always the best, as it likes to lag a LOT, It might just be me, though. Eh, who knows. Good variety of class choice, but they're genderlocked, so -1 for customization. The very buggy, and annoying "HackShield" always seems to♥♥♥♥♥♥its pants at random times, causing the game to crash, and me having to reinstall Dragon Nest. Multiple times, If I may add. Overall opinion?; Good combat, good graphics, good storyline. but♥♥♥♥♥♥everything else.

content:
Posted: April 10
												Seriously. This game is good. It's got real action based combat. The moves are like over the top fighting game specials. They even have a combo system. There's no filler. Every move has a purpose and is fun to use. It has a feeling unlike any other MMO out there. The story, amazingly, is really top notch. The presentation is exceptional. Yeah, the player wipe sucked. I lost my character too. But, it's pretty easy to get back to max level and there are other really interesting classes you can play to freshen it up. Each one even has it's own unique story. The graphics aren't demanding at all, any computer can run it, but it still looks really good somehow. They are also pretty generous with F2P items. You get special real money items every time you level up. Come and join me!

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												Don't play this game.It was formally my absolute favourite thing to play, and I spent all day playing this game, doing end game content and improving my gear dilligently. However, in recent times the DEV's and GM's have ruined this game with pay to win aspects up the♥♥♥♥♥ The costume items in this game now give you MORE stats/damage than the BEST gear in the game. It is horrible.Dragon Nest was a wonderful game; but it is now a shadow of what it once was, I strong recommend NOT playing this game, even casually. The community on this game is quickly devolving into a community akin to League of Legends on a smaller scale. The content in this game has gotten increasingly easier over the years, taking away all the challenge and charm that the game had going for it, the only thing that is 'difficult' in this game would be PvP. I'd say only play this game if you LOVE PvP. I am absolutely disappointed and upset to be writing such a bad review about a game I have played for years, with my steam account accumilating over 2000 hours, let alone the many, many more hours I had been playing it before I linked it up to steam. Dragon Nest is a dying game whose developers are just milking their cash cow, the Game Masters 80% of the time have no idea what is going on with the game, especially when it comes to bugs. The amount of cash events that have been coming out is ridiculous: "Spend x amount and get x bull♥♥♥♥♥♥cash item."Thanks for the read, sorry to say but you'd be better off investing your time into another MMO.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												dafksdj;fkja;dksfj; THIS GAME IS ONE OF THE BEST FREE TO PLAYS IN EXISTENCE.The combat is spectacular. Never, in any game I have played so far, have I seen such a well-thought-out and complete combat system that allows everyone their own style and flair. It might be one of the coolest combat systems in existence. It's grand, and playing with others makes it so much more fun, to chain combos with others. It's not a FPS, its third-person and allows for so much more freedom. And you get to see spells being cast and moves being made, which makes so much cooler.The monsters are ridiculously easy, but that is overshadowed by the fact that there isn't much grinding in this game. Except for the time I had to wait 10 levels hoping and praying that I would get a wand in a random drop. This game isn't asking for your money unless you want really fancy mounts or cosmetics or costumes; it provides everything you need for free without grinding, and you get everything you need as you progress through the game.I will say that there may be too little clothes for comfort. But the character design and story is mindblowing. Serious props to the devs for taking 9 different classes and creating an overarching storyline that differs in litte ways for each class.And its also not TOO easy -- while leveling up is relatively fast, you need to spend your Skill Points wisely to get new skills and manage your old ones. And the class trees that allow specialization are great, and make the game take on so much more variety. Its great that any two people who start off with the same class will end the game with totally different specializations and playstyles.Overall, the pro's of this amazing game overshadow any possible cons. Great storyline, amazing combat, smart decision-making, and great design.Go get it!

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												About the game: Dragon nest is an action packed MMORPG. It features unique storylines for each character as well as a great combat system later during the game(Low levels is a bit slow, but it gets MUCH better). It has Nests that you tackle in a party that are an okay difficulty, and normal dungeons you could solo. Nests scale with party somewhat, making it a bit easier solo but fun in a party. TLDR; A great action packed MMORPG with combat like no other. It has unique storylines and fun characters + dialogue. It has okay balancing, along with decent group content as well as some solo content. The latest system; the awakening system polishes up classes so they are more defined than ever before. Every character plays even more vastly different than they did before. The leveling phase is a bit bad at first, but if you can push through and maybe get some friends you can definitely enjoy this mmo. Positives:  - NOT OWNED BY NEXON ANYMORE.  - They've been VERY generous with item giveaways and events so far and its a blast.  - Great combat. Top notch among mmos. No action mmo has come close to this one.  - Decent soundtrack  - Good storylines. Every character is different, some are cliche.. and are REALLY weird.  - Okay questing system, will reach you to level cap for the most part with minimal grinding, it has a tiny bit of grind, but it will bring you through for the most part.  - Decent PvP, a little balance issues right now. But its short and sweet now.  - The new awakening system feels fresh, and it makes the game feel much more smooth.  Negatives:  - Okay amount of content, if you play as much as a regular person its good.  - A bit repetitive with mob types as well as questing. Sometimes you repeat the same dungeon.  - Not all awakenings are released for every class, sadly this does make a bit of a balance gap at the moment.  - Leveling system is quite painful the first time through, but if you get through it becomes an amazing game.Conclusion:A great mmo with more upcoming content as well as new classes. As action packed as it is fast paced its also pretty challenging and has very fluid combat. If you want to try it add VencirGan and maybe bring a couple friends with you to dull out the leveling phase. I've been playing a lot recently and I wouldn't mind helping newcomers level up, so if you want to give it a try give me a shout!RATING: 8/10

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												While I have played this game for a long time, I've had my fun with it. The combo system is good, but rarely has any effects on actual gameplay other than PVP where literally you cannot win without better stats. This game isn't as Skill to Win as it used to be, according to most of my friends who have played it for a long time. Although this game has a pretty good base and whatnot, grinding on the same dungeons just becomes really boring. Do I recommend this game? Yes!!!The PVP system is a bit flawed, but I can see where it has its fun parts. The dungeon and EXP system itself are pretty good, looting system along with them. But I do not encourage buying stuff in this game with real money, since it's pretty much just a waste.The variety of classes in this game is also a good thing to mention. But some classes definitely rise up higher than others do, which really disappoints me.The story becomes really repetitive but the only entertaining parts are when you get to actually see the story of your own character. Other than that, it's just the main story of the game.But it's all worth it.

content:
Posted: February 28
												Hi, I'm an adventurer of indisclosed gender who randomly came upon a village one day and decided to save a girl I've met only once while she was being chased by a harpy. On the way to being savior of the world I killed every single one of the people dear to me by miraculously trusting the hidden villain 10 times out of 10. But I got a cool weapon from this dragon I killed and it's all okay.I used to give crap to Argenta for verbally abusing me every minute she sees me but she really is right. I am an utterly incompetent fool. I run around making bigger messes of everything, messes that often require one or another npc's life to clean up.But in all seriousness, DN is a decent game.It's a fun time waster. The battle system is fun and I didn't mind the grind (which, compared to some of the mmorpgs I've played in the past, wasn't really difficult at all. When I picked it back up I made cap on my legacy whatever char in 3 days and the other one hit 90s in a week, I wasn't even playing nonstop). I got bored eventually because I didn't really feel committed. And as for the story, well. I guess it's interesting, I was intrigued enough to follow it despite having to run the same 3 dungeons on repeat for each part (honestly, who decides to live in a place constantly infected with monstrocities and decide not to move?) But I was really serious when I say the PC is literally the stupidest, most gullible person alive. The main quest is always the shady person out of the cast of the characters asking you to fetch some god awful, powerful evil device for "good" and the pc shrugging and saying "Why not? What harm could you possibly do with it, guy I just met yesterday?" Tldr; If you like the battle system and don't mind playing it like a solo player (because just about everything except hardcore endgame content is doable alone if you have enough time and skill), then this is great. If you are expecting a welcome community, this isn't for you. If not for having friends that asked me to play this game with them I could probably go from level 1 to cap without talking to a single soul and that's something most people (me included) is not prepared to do.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2012
												(Note: my steam playtime does not show my playtime with Nexon's standalone launcher from during the beta, actual playtime is around 80 hours)With regards to the PvE content, it contains the standard MMO tropes of leveling: experience points and stat based gear progression.The dungeons are fun, the monsters are neat, and the storyline is alright.The varied enemy types actually do different attacks and have slightly different A.I., even between palatte swaps.  If it looks different, it behaves differently.The cut scenes are entertaining i suppose, but its really all about combat.Leveling does eventually slow down dramatcially, once you run out of the standard "go kill everything in this dungeon" quests, requiring you to re-play dungeons and boss rooms, over and over, just to level up.With regards to the actual overall character progression, its mainly about upgrading your weapons (and armor too of course).This is where the Pay to Win comes in, but ill get to that in a minute.If you want to upgrade an item, you can minimally improve it up until level eight (the weapons level, not the character).Every time you upgrade an item, you spend the materials to perform the upgrade.Occasionally, the upgrade fails, meaning you lose the mats but keep the item.After level eight, you risk several random outcomes: breaking the weapon (or armor) entirely, downgrading the weapon by 3 levels, merely losing your mats with no change in stats,or actually upgrading the item by one level.The potential to completely lose your item is very real, and is especially painful, making you go back to previously played content to get a replacement, which you would then need to upgrade again.So, you can lose your item on a bad "roll" of the upgrade luck dice (metaphorical).What can be done about this?You can pay real money to buy "seals", which protect your item from breaking. (but not from the other potentially bad outcomes, such as deleveling the item.)The pay to win ethos permeates the rest of the game as well, with visual changes not actually being tied to the majority of the gear you can get through gameplay.Its sort of like if TF2 only let you buy hats, no crafting, no drops; they can only be bought with real money.The other problem with these "costume" items, is that they also give your character stats, such as "permenant run speed increase of X %", or "+ str, + int" etc.Now, on to the PvP stuff!  This is where DN shines.The PvP combat is epic, there are juggles, and tons of fun to use skills on timers (much like WoW).  DN combat is more about positional awareness, but it still relies on knowing what cooldowns are not active for your enemies.However, since there are juggles, if your "get out of a juggle" cooldowns are cooling down, then you're just hosed and can take a significant amount of damage while not being able to do anything about it, much like playing Marvel vs Capcom.This issue is even more present, since you're fighting more than one enemy at a time.Also, since DN is so focused on what gear you have and how upgraded it is, you are forced to play the PvE to level up, to get good gear, and to get the mats to improve your gear.  Additionally this means that PvP is more of a side thought, than a legitimate alternate way to level up or progress.Overall i had tons of fun with DN, but once you understand the upgrade system, why it is Pay to Win, and how PvE recycles content, id say its a worthy way to spend some time, but ultimately i felt cheated by its Cash Shop.Beware, Nexon may only be the distributor, but all of their games are notorious for abusing the Cash Shop mechanic, just like Dragon Nest does.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Dragon Nest is probably one of the top 5 Free MMORPGs out there. With a top notch combat leveling system, and best in class PvP action, Dragon nest is defently a game that should be considered playing, if a fan of MMOs. The game starts you off with selecting a class of your choice and each of these classes have their own seperate main story lines that really add to the replayability. Keep in mind that these classes are gender locked and in total have 9 different options to chose from, The art style of the game is more anime and some of the NPC voice acting is hard to get through without cringing. The soundtrack is honestly top notch and when parred with the soundeffects of the game from the skills/abilities or simply basic attacking, creates an audio masterpiece. PvE inculdes a long enjoyable story sepperate for each class, alongside 100s of side quests and daily quests. PvP is extremely fun, arguably the best of all MMOs, all though, i wouldent recomend before level 35, due to most of the PvP community consists of max level charecters (90), and due to them being max level, not only do they have more experience, but they can easily trap you in a chain of attacks due to your lack of skills at a low level. Dragon nest is a heavily instansed bassed game, but if you can get passed the 5-15 seconds loading screens, this shouldent bother you. In the terms of character customisation, outside of the cash shop, your options are extremely lacking, however if you are willing to invest 5-10 dollars, you can begin to gain some freedom. On the topic of the cash shop, there are tons of options for not only costume, but actual in-game items aswell. Through steam you are able to use your steam wallet for the cash shop.Pros:-Top notch combat.-Tons of content in PvE.-Outstanding party play.-Unique dungeons.-Very cool combat animations.-Dungeons rate performances.-Competative and Enjoyable PvP.-Main Story line differs for each class.-Consistant art style .Cons:-Charecter appearence customisation is EXTREMELY lacking outside of the cash shop and micro transactions-Gender locked classes.-Some of the faces are just.....bad.-No customisable UI.-Heavily instansed bassed game.-Cringe worthy voice acting.-while yes there are a lot of side quests, some of them are straight up anoying.

Now I couldn't even jokingly suggest someone play this unless you are okay with there being nothing but a condensed story and the game being too easy to even learn your class until the level cap.Played far too much before getting the Steam version to fix a bugged skill on one character, but now... wasted download. content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I used to play on SEA server, and if I still remember correctly, Steam would put player on NA server I think?But the review would include both perspective anyway.Pros:-You get to kill dragon, gotta kill them all, Drago----you get to shoot beam from your swords, cast laser beam from the heavens, time stop people, shoot nightmarish arrows that chases people forever, launch a horde of ducks, play with Thor Hammer and even feel fabulous with lightning sparks booming around you.-Immersive combat system for both pve and pvp, very-Socially fun, especially with your friends IRL.Neutral (as varies between different country servers):-music-character (including npc) voicing-events (lay mostly on effort side instead of real-cash bonus side)Cons:-class discrimination and inbalance exists-hack and slashes skills does not cut through clothes-grind-repetetive-RNG over RNG over RNG, and effort intolerance.-gear can be accessed into a higher level in pvp with pay2win contents.-long loading screen throughout the world if you do not have a good spec-most of those Pros only applies in Late Game.despite being a free MMO (as usual), I'd still say the pros overweight the cons, though I would still not recommend it to player that are planning to dedicate most of their lifetime on this one since it gradually dies down and lower the element of [social entertainment]. 6/10 would definitely solo a dragon again with dead team mates.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Honestly, I do not see how this game has a 'very positive' review score when compared to similar Free-to-play Action MMORPGs. First of all, the combat is very good. When you attack and kill things it has weight to it. You feel like you are striking your foes. But that is all that is good in this game.THE BAD:The UI is clunky and not customizable at all. You can't even see more then one action bar. You can't move UI elements to appease. These are things that should be standard in any MMO since 2003.You can't keybind more then one action bar full of actions. 1-8 is all you can assign and you have 3 classes worth of skills. This is nonsense.Loading screens everywhere! Join a dungeon, loading screen. Kill two groups of mobs, loading screen to next area. Kill a group of mobs, go to loading screen to next area. That is INSANE! More loading screens than a PSOne game.Balance. The game is way, way too easy. From what I read on the forums they nerfed enemy damage and increased EXP multiplier so that you can reach level cap really fast. So people migth think that is a good thing but to me, personally, it is not. Learning the game is half the fun. Do you really want idiots that barely know how to play in PvP and in your Guild because they reached max level cap in less than a week? There is no way they know their class.Loot at the end of the dungeon/raid is random. So it's very possible that you do a dungeon over  many, many times to get a piece of a equipment that you want. This is crazy. I had to do a dungeon 10 times before I finally got a better weapon.Cash Shop is full of "7-day" items. You basically pay real money for temporary items. I know it's common in most Korean MMOs but this is complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. All real-money transactions should be permanantly tied to your account.Another problem is if you go on hiatus for a month they lock your account. Don't be surprised if when you come back from vacation your characters will be gone. You have to contact support and provide detailed information to get it back. This can take up to a week and by then you probably don't want to play anymore.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												It's like COD, except not first person, not a shooting game, doesn't have dlc, is completely free, and isn't a rehashed pile of sh*t.Being serious though, it truly is a pretty good game. Sure, the difficulty is p*ss easy until some end-game raids, and running the same dungeons over and over can get a little repetitive, but if you like mmorpgs with very flashy abilities, this is a great game. I remember reading once that the Alchemist class has an ability with so many flashing lights, it tends to crash people's computers (it then got blacklisted from many PvP tournaments). There isn't any real need to spend real money, as there are no pay-walls and the 'special' gear is mostly just cosmetics. I wouldn't recommend it for everyone, but it is free-to-play, so all you're really losing is your time (which I think is well spent, as it is always fun pummeling monsters). Another really nice thing is that the story is actually really interesting. Each character has their own story line too, and my personal favorite is the Assassin one, which has to do with time travel, though I won't spoil it. My one problem with this game is that too few clothes are worn. But some people would consider that a plus.And hey, it's not under Nexon anymore. That's gotta count for something, right?

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Dragon Nest is a rare gem in the vast market of free to play MMOs. The game requires dedication, but if you stick with it the game can be extremely fun. The community is wonderful, and most people are willing to help. Make sure you join a guild because they will probably be more than willing to help you out. The first guild I ever joined was willing to gear me when I reached the previous level cap ( no guild I was ever a part of in Wow would do that). I am still with that guild and glad that I have stuck with them. The only real downside to the game is the time it takes for new content to come out. If nexon would keep the US servers up with the servers in SEA that would be awesome. So, in closing I would just like to state that dragon nest is one of the best MMOs you could ever play, but be prepared to spend some time and maybe a little money (only if you want to look awesome).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Dragon Nest is a Free-To-Play RPG online game. It includes PvP, trade, dungeons, action and more cool stuff to keep you entertained for hours! I love this game and I recommend this game for everyone of all ages. If you're looking for a free, adventure packed online game, you've come to the right place. DN also includes character customization, awesome cutscenes, helpful NPCs, enhancing items and towns to meet up with friends... or make new ones. We can't forget Parties or Guilds, you can make those too!The designs and scenery are beautiful, and the enemies are easily beat in a team. This game is a 9/10 for me. (:

												wow, great game, and im just starting out. why play this game? ive tried countless mmos, and most follow the same pattern, click enemy to attack, sell your stuff, level up lame attacks, oh, and dont forget to occasionally get cool stuff, if you pay alot.this mmo offers not only a variety of classes, but very smooth transitioning between quests, as well as a good map, nice interface, and awesome graphics. my only complaints are: 1. the classes are gender based. this doesnt ruin the game one bit for me, it would just be nice if perhaps i could play a male engineer, or a female assassin, or whatever opposite gender they have2. the game can be a bit laggy in the main hub like areas, although i do play the game on a less than ideal computer, so this can also be disregarded.3. the overall choices based on character looks are suboptimal at best, with a handful of hairdoes, colors, and eyes. though no worries as youll hardly see the face anyways, and all the few hairstyles the DO offer are pretty good looking anyways.aside from these, i HIGHLY recommend the game. if your searching steam for a good rich, awesome class based mmo to download, take it from me whos downlaoded 20+ different ones and at least give this one a try. :o)

												ive played this game for 4 Years and it is one hell of an rpg, commuinity is awesome players are awesome and 50/50 chance you will get help if you need it, but this game reqires dedecation i never really got the chance to talk to a dev/GM in all the time i played but i heard they are preety cool. Anyways if you are looking for an awesome rpg this is one to try out, but i must warn you, it is a pay to be able to kick♥♥♥♥♥in pve type of game, pay to win if you would like me to put it a better way. in this game if you want the best gear you got to be fully loaded not in cash but in gear, you have to be ready for anything the enemys throw your way and in order to increase your gear to top notch you need to spend cash so that you wont lose to the clumsy black smith who should be a pro at crafting gear . Anyways if you havent tryed this give it a try even though i wrote all of the above, give it a try it is a good game and if you like it and say to your self that you are going to dedicate your self to it, then spend cash on it ''pro tip'' leave the vanity items for last and craft your gear first. crafting your gear to 6 is free but byond that point it will break. look for the shop and buy jellys and you will be able to use that to protect your gear from breaking. oh and one last thing looks can be deciving in this game some people dont have good gear and can play very good and other look really expericed but they dont play that great so if they need help give em a hand maybe one day they will help you. teamwork is the keyin this game. 10/10 for me just wish getting jellys was much easy if you have questions about anything just send me a Message and il help you out with what i can.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												Dragon Nest has me questioning why I didn't get into action MMO's sooner.The game itself has a relatively small community, but offers some awesome content and events for the players that do consistently log on. It sports some anime inspired graphics. While still giving some insanely cool and much more dark detail to most mobs and each boss at the end of every portal.Dragon Nest starts you out in a city called "Mana Ridge" which unfortunately seems like a cliche, because it ♥♥♥♥ing is. The game doesn't really start being eye popping until you step outside of the city and engage in your first dungeon. At that point I find you start to really appreciate the games graphical prowess and charming game mechanics. While being cliche with the story and theme, Dragon Nest really does well with its combat. It has you enter a portal into a certain area (think Guild Wars), and from that you can choose one of the varied number of "runs" you can take from there; you then have 5 options for which difficulty you want to run the dungeon on, easy for chumps or abyss for MEN. If I choose abyss (which the game recommends you only do in a party of 4), not only am I a badass mother ♥♥♥♥er. But I also get the advantage of better loot, and more rewards and XP at the end of the run. This part of Dragon Nest has always been my favorite thing in the game, even though the idea isn't original, and even though it literally has you do the same thing over and over.That being said, the game sucks in these categories. Well, one category. PvP. When it was released, it was the biggest cluster ♥♥♥♥ you could imagine. It promised fluid attacks, and engaging combat. What it did deliver was a trash hitbox system and incredibly out of balance classes. One lower leveled warrior could hit a stun, and just slaughter people. It drew a very distinct line between PvE and PvP oriented classes. I played it again recently on a new character and while some of the before ignored issues were resolved (The hit boxes are much much better now) It just didn't have the charisma the PvE combat had and continues to seperate and distinguish classes as PvP or PvE oriented. Especially warriors. They still stomp everybody.So, in closing. Although very cliche at a first glance, and lacking in PvP gameplay. The game does definitely offer an outstanding time for a group of friends or for somebody looking to kill some time online. If you don't mind being called a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for playing anyway.nexon/10

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												DN has gone way downhill as support for the game has weakened...- Aside from the smooth satisfying combat (when your not lagging) the game is lacking in content and quite boring.- Has repetitive holiday events and offers very little innovation into its genre. - Guild support is bare-bones and quite pointless/unnecessary. - DN is VERY punishing to new players that don't have friends to hold their hand upon arriving at max level. - Promotes PTW.- Very poor servers, making PvP feel like its a joke and PvE feel unfair at times (but not as often).  - Majority of the community is quite bad at the game (my opinion), making it hard for them to get with parties so they can improve. (unless they have a friend/guild willing to hold  their hand) - NO BENEFITS for helping new players. No worthwhile rewards are guaranteed to helping new players/doing old content (this WAS shown in the form of the "fledgling bonus" which gave extra drops to a players first time doing a nest, it was removed)2.5/10tl;drAmazing combat Pathetic overall execution/innovationBad communityLaughable serversVery punishing to new players-This could change with T5 but as of now not worth the time.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												I'd recommend this game to you if it was still 2012.This game has turned to ♥♥♥♥ to be completely honest - and it has done so in almost every aspect thinkable. The story is boringly repetetive and cliche, the servers lag in most countries so you will teleport back and forth and not be able to hit anything, the community is pretty much non-existant and the people left are max level so they'll ignore you, the devs changed the difficulty system so you may now only play the early levels on the easiest settings, and worst of all: the game is far too easy.It seems to have the opposite problem to most mmos, in that it's not 'grindy' or difficult, it's just running through every dungeon and killing everything a few times and then moving onto the next dungeon (It is grindy in that aspect). It feels more like a poorly made and boringly long singleplayer game that still has the lag issues of being a f2p asian mmo. Playing this is just like waiting for the ending to come, and if a game has that quality, then just go back to real life since it's the same♥♥♥♥♥♥ but with characters that actually matter.The only way I recommend this game is if you bring together a bunch of friends and play through it in short bursts as a party whilst not taking it too seriously. In 2012/13 you could have done this with players you met in game, but now the only community left are at max level as stated.Base Game: 7/10What You Get: 4/10

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												I tried this game a few years back because it was cute and challenging. The skillbased attack and dodge system meant you could challenge much stronger enemies if you paid attention, giving you a shot as only slightly better gear. All around it was fun and didn't require a large time commitment. I really liked the boss battles, where they had a ton of HP, an interesting ability rotation and the ability to spawn minions at certain points.Now it is terribly boring. They give you so many over powered costume and item sets for advancing through the starting levels that you blow up everything in your path. Bosses get one-shoted! I like my costume. I look cool and the costume buffs you up. Now I no longer have any incentive to collect other items. You also gain XP so quickly that all the quests I can access are no longer a challenge and I don't see a way to move to a tougher area. This game is totally unbalanced and from what I have heard has no end game.It has wonderful art direction and I really would like to enjoy it. I tried a naked run to see if that would make things fun again. I still destroyed everything. The bosses lasted for almost a minute. It just makes me sad.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
Dragon Nest is a fast paced, hack-and-slash MMORPG. I enjoy the many classes and advancements in Dragon Nest, such as the Warrior, Cleric, or Assassin! Obviously there's more than those three. Dragon Nest is almost revolutionary due to having a different fighting style, not just point and click.Overall: I'd give it a 6.8/10. There is so much to the game already, but there can be more that could be improved.Controls & Handling: 8/10. The controls are easy to learn, but it ranges from class to class. The Warrior is immensely faster than any other class due to unlocking the dash ability at level 10.Graphics: 5/10. The graphics are subpar compared to other games such as Aion: Ascension or Guild Wars 2, but it gets the job done. The main point of Dragon Nest is definitely not graphicsStoryline: 8/10. The storyline is centered around your specific class saving the world, which is kind of stereotypical, but once you get into the game, it goes into the lore. Such as the  aging difference of archers/elves or how the Cleric becomes high priest of an organization. Really tedious to start, but great to read through once you've gotten interested.Music: 6/10. The music kind of just... fits. Although, during dungeons it can be quiet until you start attacking an enemy, but once the music gets going, you really get hyped for battle and it makes you have a sense of urgency.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Nexon has developed a reputation for releasing games that, while great on a gameplay level, are filled with microtransactions and alterations to the game to force you to buy them. While Dragon Nest continues this legacy to a degree, it's not as bad as other games the company has put out. From a gameplay standpoint Dragon Nest is very fun with its combo-based combat. The six classes (as of this review) are all fun to play in their own ways, and the specializations they can take let them further define their styles in unique ways. While the early levels can be a bit of a slog, once you get to around level 30 the game really opens up in terms of the skills you get. And whether your fighting alone, with a friend, or against a friend the combat is always enjoyable.It's unfortunate then that the rest of the game around it is a little shallow. Quests are your standard affair, either go here and kill this or go here and collect this. A few quests spice things up in interesting ways such as giving you an overpowered NPC helper or giving you a unique enemy to fight, but such quests are few and far between. Thankfully if fighting AI monsters gets boring you can always fight your fellow man in PvP. PvP is fairly balanced (with a few exceptions) with an emphasis on personal skill rather than your gear and stats.This brings me to the much despised part of any Nexon game, the cash shop. While games like Mabinogi and Maplestory are pretty much pay-to-win when it comes to their cash shop, Dragon Nest really doesn't feel that way. Sure the costumes give nice stat boosts and there are items that protect your gear from breaking while enhancing them, but such things aren't necessary unless your absolutely serious about min-maxing. Even then you should be fine as long as you invest in a decent skill build and have practiced enough to use your skills to their fullest. You even get a special level up reward box that gives out certain cash shop items like storage and inventory space, meaning you don't have to spend a dime so long as your patient.I have a feeling alot of people have/will blow this game off just because Nexon is publishing it, which is a shame. While it has its flaws Dragon Nest is a pretty decent action game if you put some time in it. It might not be the best game ever but it certainly is leagues above some of Nexon's other games. I advise you to give it a try and at least play up till level 30 or so before you pass your final judgement on the game.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This is a game with similar gameplay to other action mmos such as Vindictus, C9, etc. At first I was skeptical of this game but it actually provides a decent amount of fun. I took the time to try out different classes to see how they were and I can say each class seems worth playing, never did I feel like any class was downright boring, useless or underpowered. You do normal attacks using the left mouse button and special attacks, which are usually kicks, with the right mouse button. One thing I didn't quite like was the fact that your skills are all placed on hotkeys, which imo, defeats the purpose of this game being an action mmo. The graphics are childlike in appearance and remind me a lot of the Final Fantasy Crystal Chronicles series though it's a little disturbing how this game is with certain female characters and also "panty shots".When you create a character, you get a choice between 3 or 4 different hairstyles and clothing options, giving this game very minimal appearance customization. Overall this game seems good for what it is but I can't recommend it over Vindictus though for people who don't care for Vindictus, you could certainly do worse than this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Dragon Nest is not a normal MMORPG, it is one of the best rpg's I've ever played it doesn't use cheap auto attacking it has a real hack n' slash system in the game.  It takes skill to play this you need to be ready to dodge strike critical strike and power strike.  The graphics are very nice and the bloom is very fitting.  The game has multiple characters that may be gender locked but it's still very fun to play.  It has an actual story with real cutscenes and voice acting and I find the story very interesting to follow.  I would recommend this to anyone who wants a nice new fresh experience in rpgs.  The game does a great job of making you feel like a bad♥♥♥♥♥at a low level and you just feel so awesome when you take on giant bosses all by yourself I just love it!  Please if any of my friends get this game msg me we will play right away!.9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Dragon Nest is, in my opinion, an incredible game. I can't really think of anything I don't like about it, although I'm sure there's a few flaws in it, they're certainly not significant at all. The art is genuinely pleasing for an anime-style game, there's a pretty good choice of classes, with my only complaint being that they are genderlocked, but I haven't really found that to be much of a problem, personally. I like all of the dungeons and how they all have their own theme and the different difficulties are definitely a nice bonus. I find that it is also quite possible to be good at the game without spending money on it, and the Dragon Vault gives good options for character customization by allowing different durations for the equipment items, along with stats on most of them. I find Dragon Nest to be an all around amazing game, currently my favorite, and I would definitely recommend it. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												It's pretty much a World of Warcraft C9/Vindictus graphics wise. C9 and Vindictus are dead, Dragon Nest is still very much alive. The combos aren't nearly as good as C9, which makes it very newbie friendly, but at the same time the Raids are much more difficult, catering to the hardcore players. If you give this game a shot, at least play until level 24, when you get the fun skills. When I first tried it out I dismissed it at level 12 or so because it was generic, but obviously I just didn't have any of the good skills by then. They really did a good job distributing buffs and debuffs throughout the classes, every raid contains no multiples, and the ones that do only have one or two, making most classes desirable. As for p2win, you can get virtually everything by grinding, which may take a bit, but it's certainly not as p2win as most other F2P titles. The only major downside is the gender locked classes, the tinkerer looks like she's an 8 year old girl... But if you can see past that, it's most definitely one of the best games out there.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2013
												When you think about people Role Playing you probably cringe, but Dragon's Nest is a master piece where you might find yourself naturally role playing. You put yourself into your character. People become your close friends. You are extremely social and you wonder why you can't be like that in real life. Well I'm talking about myself here but maybe you can relate. Anyway, This game is like a over the shoulder dungeoning mmorpg and it's pretty fun. It's genderlocked and there's little customization as far as default goes but that's honestly not even a big deal it like doesn't bother me at all what so ever. It bothers me on other games but this game is just like so good that you over look the cons. except for one con that you can't possibly over look, and that's the fact that it's in the hands of Nexon. But whatever, only slight lag and it's not really pay to win. Furthermore PvP is pretty balanced.TL;DR 3rd person fun MMORPG play it unless you generally enjoy your♥♥♥♥♥♥taste.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Dragon Nest is like your classic RPG. You do quests and level up, yada yada ya. However, unlike games such as Mabinogi or WoW, the combat system embraces fluidity of skills. It's not turn-based and moves can be used whenever they're available during dungeons. The skill point system can be tailored to one's playstyle. It's quite enjoyable to play with friends, but playing in public parties is tolerable. The currency is easily gained and lost through progression and you don't need to spend money to access moves or slots for moves *cough* Spiral Knights *cough*. The NX cash shop, or the Dragon Vault, presents a variety of items such as costumes, which you don't really need to succeed, or functional consumables which the game gives you for free. The game's content is ever-expanding in the storyline and a lot of effort is put into it (even if most of you probably click as fast as you can through quests without reading). There aren't a multitude of downsides that can't be solved by the player themselves, but first and foremost: Dragon Nest is licensed (?) through Nexon. Their customer support is horrid. The couple of weeks before December had a lot of problems with connection, disconnection, and overall lag. However, the compensation for issues is usually worth it. Another problem is that single-player play can get monotonous because like many RPGs, the game is grindy, but that can either be remedied by playing in a party or y'know, taking a break. The community is riddled with individuals of almost all ages, ranging from the stereotypical whiny, slightly-illiterate "twelve-year old", to people who are married and have kids. One last drawback is that to run certain dungeons (nests), public parties usually require players to already be geared upon joining, however many guilds and other players are nice enough to help individuals who are new to levels and the game overall.edit: elaborated monotony

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												First off, you more likely to enjoy this game if you enjoy anime and manga (Japanese Media), since the chracters and art is stylized in that direction. I wouldn't say that all people who enjoy anime would enjoy this game, its just a common trend I've seen in players. Things that I've been Impressed in this game:STORY: As a F2P game, its got cut scenes and great voice acting for many of the characters. If invest the time, you can find a variety of amusing and deep storyline in the game.USER FREINDLY: Well, its a typical Fantasy Rpg, with skills binded to action hot keys. The Games Dugeon to Dugeon action makes playing the game simple and user freindly.  Death dosn't have a major penalty and PVP play is available in specificl chanaels.RE-PLAYABILITY: This game encourages replay ability, if gives you XP buffs to your characters though the Unified Skill system, you have Server (cross character) storage as well as a mailing system to send stuff back and forth between characters. And since theres multiple characters with multiple prestige classes, theres plenty of variety in game play styles.If you haven't played a Nexon Game yet, you shoudl definitely give this game of Vindictus a try. It's very user freindly and have very satisfying gameplay

If you've never played an MMO, this is a good place to start. It even manages to scale nicely with dual AMD cards, which is something quite a few newer games fail to manage.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Ok, I'm going to have to preface my review of this game with saying that I do not have at the time of this review, a character at the level 70 level cap. I plan to do so though.As with all of my other reviews, they will be scaled from 0 to 10 on a few criteria.Gameplay: 7.5/10: This game would get a perfect 10, if a few things were reduced/removed. A. GRINDING, Be prepared to grind your♥♥♥♥♥off in this game. When the game's level cap was 50, it took me several MONTHS to hit 50 on my non-boosted toon. B. Gear Upgrading, Ok, so in this game like classic Nexon fasion there is a gear upgrading ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t system. You have to spend real money to get anywhere near past about +10 on your gear, though some people are generous enough to post the jellies on the Auction House, for ♥♥♥♥TONS of Gold... These are the only things really hampering the gameplay. Otherwise, it's very fun, action based MMORPG with alot of flashy skills.Graphics: 9/10: This game would again get a perfect 10, if 1 thing was tweaked. visual effects of the Tinkerer class. 


YouTube™ Video: Dragon Nest in a Nutshell 4 - Academic/Tinkerer 

			Views: 316,618		

			https://www.facebook.com/RongRongArts		

 watch that video if you want an explination (a very funny one)Audio: Japan/Korean Voices: 10/10: American Voices: 8/10:  There used to be a mod for the game that added in the Korean voice actors for all of the classes, but it didnt continue after about Kali got released, If I could read Korean, I would be playing KDN because the voices are like 3000x better in that game. The american ones are just a bit too cheezy at some times, though some lines are funny. also, Shield Charge in KDN is one of my favorite lines along with the American version of Justice Crash.Overall: 8.5 out of 10. I'm actually going to agree with IGN on this one, it's a good place to dip your toes into the F2P genera of games, and a good place to stick. PvP is fun, PvE isnt that bad, just alot of grinding. If there was a Maybe button for the Do you recommend this game, I would probably hit that one, but Yes will be good enough.Edit: This game is now in the hands of the Parent Company/Original Creators EyeDentity! So, updates will most likely come sooner, and the general quality of the game will improve!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Dragons Nest is an MMORPG game, and a pretty interesting one I find. The game isn't turn based, its actually real time, which is cool, its played from a kind of MMO view, but in a way plays sort of like Diablo. It has many different Dungeons that you go into to complete quests, and each Dungeon has a boss. There are also 6 classes, and each are pretty unique. And have some pretty cool flashy abilities, as well as 2 subclasses for each.The story I don't find to be super compelling, but its decent I guess. The graphics are a cartoonish style, which is fine and works for me really. Unless your not a fan of cartoon style it shouldn't bother you.One thing I kind of dislike about the game is the lack of customization, you can't even change your gender, each class is set to a specific gender, which is kind of disappointing as I really like customization on characters. There is very little of that in this game however. But it doesn't make the game bad or anything.The dungeons are kind of easy at first, but get pretty tough pretty steadily, before long you won't be able to do every dungeon on master difficulty with ease, and you will need to turn the difficulty lower, or get a few friends to help.Each time you enter a Dungeon you can select a difficulty, which affects how much XP you get and other rewards. And the dungeons can get challanging like I said, even if the first couple aren't especially with friends. But overall the game is pretty fun I find, especially with a buddy or two. Its a fresh nice MMO which I find enjoyable as you bash through tons of enemies alone or with your friends. And aquire juicy loot and cool spells.And the fact its free means I think you should atleast try it if you get the chance.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												I highly recommend this game but DO NOT download the STEAM VERSION. Go to Nexon's official website at http://dragonnest.nexon.net/ and download their client instead. The steam version is regularly plagued by log-in and patching issues and the only fix is to re-download the game every single time. Nexon and Steam doesn't seem to care about this version anymore.Now, on to the review! If you want action-oriented MMORPG with flashy / cool-looking moves then Dragon Nest is the game for you. You have your basic rpg classes in the form of Warrior, Archer, Cleric and Sorcerer. The other available classes are Tinkerer (a sort of engineer) and Dancer. Upcoming classes are Assassin and Lancer.The world is instance type wherein areas (including towns) are separated like dungeons. Although, the towns are very big themselves. The dungeons get bigger and bigger as you progress into the game. Lastly, the environment details are well made and numerous.You gain exp in the game by killing mobs in dungeons, clearing the dungeons themselves and completing NPC quests. When you gain a level you get skill points which you can use to unlock your skills. Core stats are pre-set by the game. Pretty much a standard level and skill system. There's a nifty feature wherein you can see a demo of a skill first before you get it. That way, you can see if you'll like the skill or not.Exp is very fast from Level 1 to 50. 50 to 70 is when the grind starts but still doable and not boring because of the awesome combat system. If you're a hardcore player that can sit a whole day in front of a computer then you can get to the level cap in a week or so. If you're a casual player like me, at level 50 onwards you can gain 2 levels a day or 4 while still being able to stand up and do other stuff. That's pretty fast by today's MMORPG standards.I won't go into the other details of the game because to be honest, it's very big even though it's instanced type. I just provided feedback on the basic features that players tend to look forward to.So again, if you're into action and flashy moves, this is the game for you. You're not really missing anything by not dowloading the Steam version so go the Nexon website I provided on this review and get their client instead. Trust me, it'll be less hassle in the long run.Nexon Dragon Nest Official Website:http://dragonnest.nexon.net/

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												I've recently gone over my review and noticed it was... rather plain, and didn't give any indication as to the actualy quality of this game, so allow me to elaborate. Dragon Nest is an Action RPG made by Nexon and, what I would call, like Vindictus' younger brother. The combat is very involved as compared to other MMORPG's and skills are very satisfying to use. All-in-all, I would say Dragon Nest is a very fun MMORPG and if you like Vindictus, you will most likely enjoy this game.Pros:- Cutesy Anime Style (Maybe a con if you're not into that?)- Runs fairly well- Satisfying/Solid Combat- Straight-forward and easy to understand- Not Pay-to-win (Last I checked anyway...)- Has the general quality one can expect from a Nexon game- Panty ShotsCons:- Progress slows down rather significantly around level 40 (Cap is like 80, I think?)- Difficult to gear-up later on- PvP is incredibly brokenThe bottom line is, I haven't really had any bad experiences with Dragon Nest, and it's F2P, so why not give it a try?

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This game is blood boilingly exciting, the combat is challenging at times, but is extremely fun. I play with my best friend and we have fun clearing the dungeons on the harder difficulties. I love experimenting with each class. (can't wait for the assassin!) I also enjoy the contrast between the character looks and the monster looks. It goes from "oh, that's nice." to "Oh GOD oh, what the hell IS that thing... THAT'S AN ORC??!! I've never seen an orc like that before. Who designed these monstrosities??!! WTF is goin on????" I love every bit of this game and I'll spend endless hours playing it in the future. Take note NOT to be discourged because of the gender-locked classes. they're fun none the less and you'll get used to them! I highly recommend this Korean Action MMORPG, to any fan of fast paced combate and unique anime-like graphics.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I haven't been playing long so if you need to decide if you are going to get this game, look to a review from someone who has spent at least 30 hrs in game.I am here to share my first impressions. I'll start with the bad: the game is very cookie cutter, story line, level grind, being usless untill level 20, and so on. I have also seen better graphics, WAY BETTER. The game also feels frustratingly easy, but takes a long  time. It's like every other F2P MMO out there. BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE!Now for the good stuff; the game is adorable, the npc's have funny personalities, It's quick to understand, and really fun, almost relaxing. But what is really unique about this game is the community. I was playing for the first time trying to figure out what to do and bam, in the first FIVE minutes I met three people (all higher level than me) just hanging around, who invited me to their party. Two minutes later they where going on all my quests with me and showing me what to do. They helped me until I reached lvl 10 when I had to get off and catch some sleep. We have keept in touch since then but it's really cool how I met them so soon and how friendly they where, I'm used to playing games where nearly everyone is "lone wolf" kinda thing but It's really nice to have people to party up with and just hang out.I'm keeping this short and sweet so overall first impression is: I'm No longer forever alone. This game is fun, have some paitience, give it a try :P.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I highly recommend that you should give this game a solid try if you haven't already. By solid try, I mean to level a character past 15 and the first specialization because, as other reviews may have noted, it's a bit of a slow starter. Your character starts off fairly weak with few impressive skills. However, that just makes the payoff that much more satisfying later when you decimate about thirty goblins in a single blow. With very few exceptions, most of the skills in this game are AoEs with no upper limit of affected targets and no reduced damage for the number of targets affected. This lends to an almost addictive feeling of raw, unadulterated power.But let's focus on what I really like about this game.This game just oozes charm. Though the graphics are not what one would expect from a top-of-the-line blockbuster, the animations are fluid to the point that one can suspend disbelief and immerse themselves in the world of Altera. This is further supplemented by the voice acting. Although I'm not a huge fan of the voice acting for the playable characters themselves, and voice acting in the cutscenes is to be expected, I've sort of fallen in love with how the NPCs are voiced. It's nothing too elaborate; each NPC has a couple of different canned lines for when you initiate a conversation with them, and a couple for when you part ways. However, they really help to bring the setting to life, especially in tandem with the humorous and well-written dialogue for the quests themselves. I often found myself re-reading the quest dialogues for quests I'd done a dozen times already, simply because I found them that funny. The story itself has plenty of twists and turns, and I always found myself wanting to charge down the main quest line just to know what happened next.I'm also a big fan of the game's mechanics. I've played games which implemented the public-instanced-town with privately-instanced-dungeons mechanic, and games which implemented the third-person shooter perspective. This one does both, and fairly well. I'm generally a fan of soloing the majority of game content, and the regular dungeons are solo-friendly. Combat is smooth, interweaving regular mouse-button attacks with hotkeyed skills so that one is rarely just spamming skills and waiting for cooldowns to reset. Gear is relatively easy to come by (though less so with the more classes added, sadly)(EDIT: They fixed that issue, as gear drops in boxes that give you a class-specific item when you open them.), as soloing Master difficulty is fairly easy and one can get "magic" green-quality gear from Master instances. Upgrading "magic" gear to +6 (+7 or more if you find extras that you can competitively upgrade until one breaks) is pretty darn cheap and gives you more than enough stats to get you through soloing abyss dungeons on pretty much any class, so I would recommend not bothering with blue or orange gear until you're near endgame and really need the stats for harder dungeons, Nests, and PvP.There are limitations, of course. The classes are gender-locked, and though you can customize your character's appearance to an extent, each of them is essentially their own pre-made character with its own story. It may also be difficult for a newer player/character to find others to level with, but joining a guild (or even just staying in the newbie guild you're automatically inserted into when your character is made) may remedy this issue.All in all, I've put a lot of hours into this game and always find myself coming out for more. Maybe it's not your thing, but I'd recommend giving it a try, anyway.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Dragons Nest is an MMORPG game, and a pretty interesting one I find. The game isn't turn based, its actually real time, which is cool, its played from a kind of MMO view, but in a way plays sort of like Diablo. It has many different Dungeons that you go into to complete quests, and each Dungeon has a boss. There are also 6 classes, and each are pretty unique. And have some pretty cool flashy abilities, as well as 2 subclasses for each.The story I don't find to be super compelling, but its decent I guess. The graphics are a cartoonish style, which is fine and works for me really. Unless your not a fan of cartoon style it shouldn't bother you.One thing I kind of dislike about the game is the lack of customization, you can't even change your gender, each class is set to a specific gender, which is kind of disappointing as I really like customization on characters. There is very little of that in this game however. But it doesn't make the game bad or anything.The dungeons are kind of easy at first, but get pretty tough pretty steadily, before long you won't be able to do every dungeon on master difficulty with ease, and you will need to turn the difficulty lower, or get a few friends to help.Each time you enter a Dungeon you can select a difficulty, which affects how much XP you get and other rewards. And the dungeons can get challanging like I said, even if the first couple aren't especially with friends. But overall the game is pretty fun I find, especially with a buddy or two. Its a fresh nice MMO which I find enjoyable as you bash through tons of enemies alone or with your friends. And aquire juicy loot and cool spells.And the fact its free means I think you should atleast try it if you get the chance.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												I've recently gone over my review and noticed it was... rather plain, and didn't give any indication as to the actualy quality of this game, so allow me to elaborate. Dragon Nest is an Action RPG made by Nexon and, what I would call, like Vindictus' younger brother. The combat is very involved as compared to other MMORPG's and skills are very satisfying to use. All-in-all, I would say Dragon Nest is a very fun MMORPG and if you like Vindictus, you will most likely enjoy this game.Pros:- Cutesy Anime Style (Maybe a con if you're not into that?)- Runs fairly well- Satisfying/Solid Combat- Straight-forward and easy to understand- Not Pay-to-win (Last I checked anyway...)- Has the general quality one can expect from a Nexon game- Panty ShotsCons:- Progress slows down rather significantly around level 40 (Cap is like 80, I think?)- Difficult to gear-up later on- PvP is incredibly brokenThe bottom line is, I haven't really had any bad experiences with Dragon Nest, and it's F2P, so why not give it a try?

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This game is blood boilingly exciting, the combat is challenging at times, but is extremely fun. I play with my best friend and we have fun clearing the dungeons on the harder difficulties. I love experimenting with each class. (can't wait for the assassin!) I also enjoy the contrast between the character looks and the monster looks. It goes from "oh, that's nice." to "Oh GOD oh, what the hell IS that thing... THAT'S AN ORC??!! I've never seen an orc like that before. Who designed these monstrosities??!! WTF is goin on????" I love every bit of this game and I'll spend endless hours playing it in the future. Take note NOT to be discourged because of the gender-locked classes. they're fun none the less and you'll get used to them! I highly recommend this Korean Action MMORPG, to any fan of fast paced combate and unique anime-like graphics.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												I highly recommend this game but DO NOT download the STEAM VERSION. Go to Nexon's official website at http://dragonnest.nexon.net/ and download their client instead. The steam version is regularly plagued by log-in and patching issues and the only fix is to re-download the game every single time. Nexon and Steam doesn't seem to care about this version anymore.Now, on to the review! If you want action-oriented MMORPG with flashy / cool-looking moves then Dragon Nest is the game for you. You have your basic rpg classes in the form of Warrior, Archer, Cleric and Sorcerer. The other available classes are Tinkerer (a sort of engineer) and Dancer. Upcoming classes are Assassin and Lancer.The world is instance type wherein areas (including towns) are separated like dungeons. Although, the towns are very big themselves. The dungeons get bigger and bigger as you progress into the game. Lastly, the environment details are well made and numerous.You gain exp in the game by killing mobs in dungeons, clearing the dungeons themselves and completing NPC quests. When you gain a level you get skill points which you can use to unlock your skills. Core stats are pre-set by the game. Pretty much a standard level and skill system. There's a nifty feature wherein you can see a demo of a skill first before you get it. That way, you can see if you'll like the skill or not.Exp is very fast from Level 1 to 50. 50 to 70 is when the grind starts but still doable and not boring because of the awesome combat system. If you're a hardcore player that can sit a whole day in front of a computer then you can get to the level cap in a week or so. If you're a casual player like me, at level 50 onwards you can gain 2 levels a day or 4 while still being able to stand up and do other stuff. That's pretty fast by today's MMORPG standards.I won't go into the other details of the game because to be honest, it's very big even though it's instanced type. I just provided feedback on the basic features that players tend to look forward to.So again, if you're into action and flashy moves, this is the game for you. You're not really missing anything by not dowloading the Steam version so go the Nexon website I provided on this review and get their client instead. Trust me, it'll be less hassle in the long run.Nexon Dragon Nest Official Website:http://dragonnest.nexon.net/
